panel.name: Display panel
panel.label: Graphics

check_box.name: windowed mode
check_box.label: Run the viewer in a window

panel.text: If unchecked, viewer will display full-screen (after restart).

check_box.name: hi_dpi_check
check_box.label: High DPI mode
check_box.tool_tip: Support for high resolution on Retina screens under macOS (BEWARE: this will more than halve your FPS rate) or user interface scaling under Windows 10.

button.name: Defaults
button.label: Recommended
button.tool_tip: Sets the settings to the recommended ones for the detected class of your graphics card (these recommended settings are rather coarse, but they are a good base for further fine-tuning).

check_box.name: benchmark_gpu_check
check_box.label: Benchmark GPU
check_box.tool_tip: Enable GPU benchmarking for class determination when applying recommended settings. Note that this setting is automatically (re)enabled when your GPU is not (yet) among the list of known models.

slider.name: GlowResolutionPow
slider.label: Quality:
slider.tool_tip: This sets the glow map resolution to either 256x256 pixels (low quality) or 512x512 pixels (high quality).

check_box.name: UsePBRCheck
check_box.label: Physically based rendering
check_box.tool_tip: With this check box you can toggle between the legacy extended environment (EE) renderer and the new physically based rendering (PBR) renderer. The latter is only available for OpenGL drivers v3.1 or newer, and lacks a forward rendering mode, i.e. ALM is always on, with what it incurs in terms of VRAM and RAM consumption, with new PBR maps (4 textures per face). This mode also changes how legacy contents looks (especially for full bright faces, no invisiprim support, etc).

check_box.name: RenderDeferred
check_box.label: Advanced lighting model
check_box.tool_tip: This settings enables deferred rendering, which allows to render materials and (optionnally) shadows. Only available if your graphics card and drivers support FBO and deferred rendering. Note that the hit of this feature requires modern CPU and GPU to avoid seeing the frame rates badly impacted.

combo_box.name: RenderShadowDetailCombo
combo_box.tool_tip: Here, you may enable shadows. Be aware however that the hit of shadows on FPS rates is extremely high, even on modern hardware !

text.name: water_altitude_text
text.tool_tip: Here, you may limit the camera (eye) altitude above which water rendering will be skipped. Setting this altitude to 0 causes the water to always render. Any other altitude will be further dynamically clamped to the draw distance. The default is 1024m.

spinner.name: WaterMaxAltitude
spinner.tool_tip: You may limit with this setting the camera (eye) altitude above which water rendering will be skipped. Setting this altitude to 0 causes the water to always render. Any other altitude will be further dynamically clamped to the draw distance. The default is 1024m.

text.name: water_text
text.tool_tip: Here, you may choose what is reflected at the water surface. Be aware however that beyond 'Terrain and trees', the hit of water reflections on FPS rates is high, even on modern hardware !

combo_box.name: WaterReflectionTypeCombo
combo_box.tool_tip: Here, you may choose what is reflected at the water surface. Be aware however that beyond 'Terrain and trees', the hit of water reflections on FPS rates is high, even on modern hardware !

check_box.name: SSRCheck
check_box.tool_tip: When this box is checked, screen space reflections are rendered to better account for dynamic objects with reflection probes. Be aware however that the hit of screen space reflections on FPS rates is high, even on modern hardware.
check_box.label: Screen space reflections

check_box.name: AvatarCloth
check_box.label: Avatar cloth shader
check_box.tool_tip: This shader is only of use for non-mesh avatars, and causes wavelets to appear on worn legacy clothing (or skin, when naked) while they fly around (i.e. when the relative wind is strong enough). This is a low power budget shader, but not really useful any more...

text.name: reflections_text
text.tool_tip: Here, you may choose what is reflected at the surface of PBR shiny materials. Be aware however that the hit of reflections on FPS rates is high, even on modern hardware, with 'Realtime' a total frame rate killer.

combo_box.name: ReflectionDetailCombo
combo_box.tool_tip: Here, you may choose what is reflected at the surface of PBR shiny materials. Be aware however that the hit of reflections on FPS rates is high, even on modern hardware, with 'Realtime' a total frame rate killer.

text.name: coverage_text
text.tool_tip: Here, you may choose what is reflection probe coverage; the wider the slower...

combo_box.name: ReflectionLevelCombo
combo_box.tool_tip: Here, you may choose what is reflection probe coverage; the wider the slower...

check_box.name: smaa
check_box.label: SMAA instead of FXAA in ALM
check_box.tool_tip: When this box is checked, anti-aliasing in ALM mode is performed via a SMAA (Sub-pixel Morphological Anti-Aliasing) shader instead of the FXAA (Fast approXimate Anti-Aliasing) shader. The advantage is that SMAA does not blur the texture details like FXAA does, but detects and anti-aliases edges only.

check_box.name: sharpen
check_box.label: Sharpen shader after AA in ALM
check_box.tool_tip: When this box is checked, anti-aliasing in ALM mode is followed with an image sharpening step (Contrast Adaptive Sharpening).

slider.name: MeshBoostFactor
slider.label: Mesh objects boost factor:
slider.tool_tip: This boost factor is a multiplicator (that should not need to be pushed beyond 2.0) for the above Objects level of detail, when the objects in questions are meshes. It allows to render badly designed meshes, all those meshes whose creator tell you to push up the RenderVolumeLODFactor setting way above its nornal maximum value (3.0) so that they can render at the right level of detail... BEWARE: if you are yourself a mesh designer, please do test your meshes with this factor set to 1.0, so that they will show up right in all viewers (especially LL's) without having to push settings way beyond the values they were designed for (pushing RenderVolumeLODFactor above 3 does have bad side effects and does cause rendering glitches with some primitives).

slider.name: SkyMeshDetail
slider.label: High altitude clouds:
slider.tool_tip: Note that this setting got almost no effect at all on the clouds prettiness (it only significatively affects the Sun disk geometry and, marginally, clouds on the horizon) but does affect negatively the FPS rate when increased... Better keeping it on low.

check_box.name: ClassicClouds
check_box.label: Low altitude clouds
check_box.tool_tip: These clouds are also known as the "classic clouds". They are particle-like clouds. Note that they have a significant impact on the frame rate when they are actually rendered (the Cool VL Viewer stops updating and rendering them on purpose when they are beyond the draw distance).

spinner.name: CloudsAltitude
spinner.label: at:
spinner.tool_tip: With this setting you can choose the average altitude of the "classic clouds" (which was fixed at 192m in old SL viewers). A negative value may be set, which will then be substracted to the agent current altitude at the moment a new cloud puff is rezzed, meaning the new cloud puffs will always be rezzed above the agent altitude with a delta height corresponding to the absolute value of that negative value. Since cloud puffs are 48m high and appear at +/-48m from the average altitude, any resulting absolute altitude below below 72m (i.e. 48 / 2 + 48) would get clamped so that the base of any cloud puff is at 0m.

check_box.name: core_gl
check_box.label: Enable core GL profile (after restart)
check_box.tool_tip: The core GL profile is especially beneficial to NVIDIA graphics cards and drivers under Linux and Windows (with sometimes *massive* FPS gains). It may be detrimental with AMD and Intel drivers. Note also that with the core GL profile activated you loose the GL lines width above 1.0 (used only in a few UI elements, such as the position edit arrows, or the old style, T-like mini-map tracking dots): these lines appear finer and are less visible.

check_box.name: ani
check_box.label: Anisotropic filtering
check_box.tool_tip: This setting is better kept enabled. It avoids blur on mostly horizontal surfaces (e.g. floor textures) textures in the distance while having little impact on frame rates (not at all with modern GPUs).

check_box.name: occlusion
check_box.label: Enable object-object occlusion
check_box.tool_tip: Speeds up rendering on hardware supporting it. However, it may also sometimes slow down things with very old GPUs: do check your frame rate while toggling this setting on/off and see what works best for your GPU and driver.

spinner.name: vram_override
spinner.label: Available VRAM (MB):
spinner.tool_tip: With this setting, you may override the amount of VRAM detected by the viewer: this is useful with bogus OpenGL drivers reporting fantaisist amounts (e.g. AMD drivers under Windows), or for iGPUs and APUs not having any VRAM at all (in this case, set a reasonable amount that can fit your system RAM). When set to 0, this lets the viewer use the auto-detected VRAM amount.

check_box.name: no_vram_check
check_box.label: Disable VRAM checks
check_box.tool_tip: With GPUs/drivers capable of it, the viewer regularly queries for the free VRAM memory and adjusts the textures LOD to make them fit. In case the reports would be broken (could happen for APUs, for example, since they do not have VRAM but use the CPU RAM), which would result in blurry textures, you can disable entirely this memory check with this setting.

slider.name: GrapicsCardTextureMemory
slider.label: Texture memory (MB):
slider.tool_tip: Amount of memory to allocate for textures. Please, do NOT confuse this memory amount with the amount of graphics card memory (VRAM): the latter is also used for the GL textures, the frame buffer, the vertex buffers, etc, so, unless texture compression is activated, you should not allocate more than half of your VRAM to the textures if you do not want the graphics driver to 'spill out' its memory allocations into the system RAM, causing a tremendous drop in FPS rates... Reducing this may improve performances but may also make textures blurry.

slider.name: max_boung_gl_tex
slider.label: Max GL bound tex (MB):
slider.tool_tip: Maximum permitted amount of GL bound textures to keep in VRAM. When too large an amount of such textures is loaded in VRAM, the GPU may end up spilling textures and vertex buffers over to the RAM, causing bad FPS 'hiccups' and sometimes seconds-long 'freezes'. Note that this setting is further bound automatically by the viewer to a portion of the available VRAM.

check_box.name: texture_compression
check_box.label: Compress textures larger than:
check_box.tool_tip: Compresses GL textures in video and driver-allocated memory, allowing for higher resolution textures to be loaded and less memory (both RAM and VRAM) to be used by the viewer, at the cost of some color quality as well as FPS rate (sometimes sever) hiccups (compressing textures takes time). Better kept off !

spinner.name: gl_threads
spinner.label: OpenGL worker threads:
spinner.tool_tip: This setting enables (when non-zero) worker threads with shared OpenGL profiles, currently used for GL images creation and deletion. This provides smoother (less spiky) and higher frame rates while textures are loaded. When enabled and to avoid a bottleneck in GL textures creation, it is recommended to set the number of GL threads to match the number of image decoder threads (as set in the Cool features tab, Misc. sub-tab); -1 ensures an automatic threads number determination, based on the number of CPU cores.

check_box.name: rgba16_check
check_box.label: Enable the RGBA16 format (read tool tip !)
check_box.tool_tip: The RGBA16 format may be used with some OpenGL v4+ capable AMD GPUs instead of the RGBA12 format, providing a better image quality. However, some AMD/ATI GPU/driver/OS combinations may cause a hanging of the driver when this format is used (the viewer would become unresponsive).

slider.name: MaxNonImpostors
slider.label: Max non-impostors
slider.tool_tip: Impostors are used to render 'muted' avatars as grey silhouettes (dark grey for full mutes, almost black for RestrainedLove visual mutes, light grey for on-demand mutes via 'Mutes>' -> 'Never show' in the avatar pie menu) and colored 'jelly-dolls' for avatar complexity mutes. They also serve for rendering avatars far away or when the amount of avatars raises above the limit set via this slider. If you disable avatar impostors (by setting this slider to 0), none of the mutes in question will be available, but for the RestrainedLove visual mutes.

slider.name: MaximumComplexity
slider.label: Maximum avatar complexity
slider.tool_tip: This is the maximum allowed avatar complexity level above wich avatars will be turned into 'jelly-dolls' on your screen (0 for no limit).

slider.name: SurfaceAreaLimit
slider.label: Maximum surface area
slider.tool_tip: Maximum surface area of attachments before an avatar is rendered as a jelly-doll (0 for no limit).

slider.name: GeometryBytesLimit
slider.label: Maximum geometry megabytes
slider.tool_tip: Maximum memory usage (in mega-bytes) of attachments before an avatar is rendered as a jelly-doll (0 for no limit).

check_box.name: AlwaysRenderFriends
check_box.label: Always render friends regardless of their avatar complexity

check_box.name: ColoredJellyDolls
check_box.label: Color jelly-dolls (too complex, impostored avatars)
check_box.tool_tip: When this box is not checked, avatars that are too complex and rendered as jelly-dolls are colored in grey, like visually muted ones, instead of a pseudo-random color.

slider.name: MaxPuppetAvatars
slider.label: Maximum animesh avatars
slider.tool_tip: Maximum number of (standalone, i.e. not attached) animesh avatars to render. Set this to 0 for no limit.

check_box.name: AvatarPhysics
check_box.label: Enable avatar physics (read carefully the tooltip for this setting)
check_box.tool_tip: This setting allows to turn on avatar physics (AKA jiggling boobs and wobbling buttocks). Note that even when your avatar is wearing a Physics wearable, avatar physics stays off unless this setting is on. Beware: this feature requires a lot of viewer side calculations and may cause a frame rate slow down, especially in crowded areas.

slider.name: AvatarPhysicsLOD
slider.label: Avatar Physics LOD factor
slider.tool_tip: This is the 'level of details' for avatar physics (AKA jiggling boobs and wobbling buttocks), which governs how often physics parameters are updated each second (the higher, the CPU power hungrier).

panel.string: Enable GPU benchmarking for class determination when applying recommended settings. Note that this setting is automatically (re)enabled when your GPU is not (yet) among the list of known models. Benchmarked memory bandwitdh is: [BW] GB/s.
The advanced lighting model is disabled. You will not see any shadow neither any material effect (bump map and specular map reflections/diffractions).

Under macOS, this setting allows to toggle between the OpenGL v2.1 compatibility profile mode, and the OpenGL v3.2 or v4.1 (depending on the macOS version) core profile mode; the latter is preferrable, as long as your Mac can do it without switching to a software rendering mode (that would totally ruin the performances), which should be the case with all modern Macs. Requires a viewer restart to take effect.
